title: Neighborhood Council 10Y
about: The Neighborhood Council (formerly Neighborhood Crime Prevention Council) for beat 10Y exists as a forum to find community solutions to ongoing problems in the neighborhoods of Longfellow (North of 40th St) and Santa Fe. We believe in a holistic approach to crime prevention and work in partnership with the City of Oakland to address ongoing problems in our neighborhoods.   Monthly meetings will be attended by a Community Resource Officer (CRO) – a specifically-designated OPD officer whose position is funded by Measure Z. Any community member (lives, works, or worships in 10Y) who wishes to regularly attend and participate in meetings is also welcome to join by signing up here. We will often have speakers from the city or community lined up for our meetings.

title.value: Why reporting a problem is important.

info.value: For many people, reporting a problem is an obvious first step to solving that problem. However, due to increasing distrust of city services, many people in Oakland are hesitant to involve the city (e.g., the police). Our NC recognizes this reality, however, we try to take a data-driven approach to understanding what problems our neighborhood is facing.  How can we solve a problem if we do not know it exists?

Whether or not you, personally, believe in the current form of policing in US cities, we urge you to find a constructive way to report the obstacles you are encountering. We will work to create multiple options for you and to build a cohesive accounting of what happens in 10Y. This section is a living document that represents our current understanding of how best to report problems Longfellow and Santa Fe neighbors encounter. Please email yates@duck.com if you have additional resources that should be listed here.

faq.title: How do I report a problem?

info.value: Depending on the problem (and whether it is a crime and whether you want to involve city services) there are several ways to report. That’s what this faq is for. (Note: this is an evolving document and will likely change as we collect more information).
From a landline, call 911*.
From a cell phone: call the Oakland Fire Department dispatch number 510-444-1616.
*911 dispatch is understaffed currently and regularly overwhelmed by a large call volume.

faq.title: I am experiencing a criminal emergency.

info.value: Depending on where the emergency occurs and whether you have access to a landline, there are different options.
Cell Phone Emergency Numbers:
<ul><li>Oakland Police: 510-777-3211
• Oakland Fire: 510-444-1616
Store these numbers in your cell phone in case of emergency.
More information can be found here.

faq.title: I have experienced a crime that is no longer an emergency

info.value: If applicable, and you want to involve the police, report the crime online.
Here are the police numbers for different types of crimes:
• Media Inquiries: (510) 238-7230
• Crime Stoppers: (510) 777-8572
• Illegal Drugs: (510) 238-3784
• Sexual Assault: (510) 637-0298

faq.title: I have a problem that is not a crime against a person or my property.

info.value: use Oak311.

The best way to report things that are problems but not person/property crimes (e.g., blocked drains, dead animals, illegal dumping) is to use 311. There are iphone and android apps that facilitate this process.
Our CRO is Officer Jason Kino (JKino@oaklandca.gov ) and the officer Sylvestre Triana (STriana@oaklandca.gov) is a helpful resource for Area 2 (North Oakland and Uptown)
If you have a problem that you do not know how to handle and you have information on, you can email yates@duck.com or email the CROs directly.
The city of Oakland has a new program for abandoned vehicles. It is quickest to email VehicleAbatement@oaklandca.gov, instead of reporting through 311.

faq.title: I have a problem and do not want to involve the police

info.value: There are several community-based organizations that are anti-police. The anti-terror project has a website and a hotline that I could not find in 5 minutes of searching their website.
https://www.antipoliceterrorproject.org/
RJoy (a.k.a. Restorative Justice for Oakland Youth) operates a  hotline for mental health emergencies. The number is (888)752-2737
Please email yates@duck.com  if you have more information on community alternatives. We aim to be inclusive and holistic in our solutions to the problems that are facing the neighborhood.

Finally, don’t let perfect be the enemy of good. Solve problems however best fits your style, but please do think about how we should best record what happens so we can create a common narrative for our neighborhood. There is no place for antagonism at NCPC meetings.
